channel.title: Michigan Football on tracker
channel.description: Recent content in Michigan Football on tracker

item.title: September 30, 2014 University of Michigan campus football protest
item.description:
"This is so much better than a home game" -protestor

— mgoblog (@mgoblog) September 30, 2014

item.title: thanks Dave Brandon
item.description:
A brisk torch and pitchfork business offsets diminished football parking revenues.

(As noted on Twitter tonight. Michigan fans have loyalty to the school, even if they are not particularly fond of this season's athletic director.)

item.title: a blow to the head, but back in the game
item.description:
The tone of Michigan football blogs has changed since the loss to Minnesota on Saturday. Before the game there was a lot of grumbling, but it was varied; no one single issue stood out. After the game, it was much more clear.

A series of plays saw the second string Michigan quarterback, Shane Morris, get hit hard on his head. Morris is seen exhibiting signs of a concussion. Yet in an unfortunate sequence he goes back into the game after sitting out one play on the sidelines.

Fans now have a pinpoint spot to point their anger at coach Brady Hoke. The team lost, but it's not all about winning and losing. What matters now is the understanding of the coaching staff and their inability to protect an obviously injured student from further harm.

Michigan has gotten funding to reduce the risk of concussions in sports. It appears that all that effort was for naught in this particular instance of not protecting a player whose judgment was impaired because of a head injury. Coach Hoke is under fire and for good reason.

item.title: the risk of misplaced enthusiasm
item.description:
At some point in the life of a project it is inevitable that an obstacle comes up that makes you wonder whether your enthusiasm for the effort is well placed.

Do you redouble your efforts, or do you take a break, or do you simply refocus and find something else to zero in on for the moment?

Sometimes a bit of distance can help, at least temporarily. Rather than exit in flames with a tattered manifesto flapping on the door in your wake, just go quiet for a while. If no one notices that you are no longer present so much, then you can free up that unrequited love and apply it to something else for a while.

(Written for all those unhappy Michigan football fans.)
